Box 125, Pohang (South Korea) (Received March 23, 1992; accepted May 13, 1992) Abstract In t-butylation of hydroquinones and condensation of methyl N-phenyl carbamate, cationexchanged sulfonic acid resin catalysts exhibited significantly better regioselectivity than liquid mineral acid catalysts. This trend was independent of the acid strength of the catalysts and the reaction conditions employed, including choice of solvent. The magnitude of the effect, however, depended on the bulkiness of the substituents. The difference between these heterogeneous and homogeneous acid catalysts was attributed to steric hindrance imposed on fixed protons in the solid catalysts, which caused higher selectivity toward the less-hindered position. Introduction Heterogeneous catalysts offer several practical advantages over their homogeneous counterparts. Most obvious is facile separation of product from catalyst. In the case of acid catalysis, solid acid catalysts provide reduced corrosion, safer handling and less polluting waste than liquid acids. However, the difference in catalytic activity and selectivity between solid and liquid acid catalysts is not obvious. We report here two examples that demonstrate that regioselectivity of some organic syntheses could be controlled by solid acid catalysts. The solid acid catalysts employed here are cation-exchanged polystyrene sulfonic acid resins (Amberlyst 15 and Amberlite Ill- 120) and aperfluorinated ion-exchanged polymer (Nafion NR-50). The former has already been applied in a number of industrial chemical processes [ 1, 21. The performance of these insoluble catalysts was compared with that of mineral liquid acids such as HZS04, HCl and H,3P04 under similar conditions. The first reaction tested was t-butylation of monosubstituted hydroquinones, where R was either methyl (MHQ), phenyl (PHQ) or t-butyl (TBHQ). *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/93/$06.00 1993 - Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. Among these, the 2,3-isomer is not likely to be formed, owing to steric hindrance by substituent R. These hydroquinones are employed as antioxidants for food [ 3-61. Condensation of methyl N-phenyl carbamate (MPC) with formaldehyde is also an acid-catalyzed reaction of considerable practical interest [ 7-101. The reaction products include 4,4'-MDU, 2,4'-MDU, trimers and N-benzyl compounds. The latter compounds, having methylene-amino bonds (1), do not produce the desired isocyanates and have a harmful influence on the next thermal decomposition step [7]. 0 P CH30CHN - I % / NCOCH3 CH2 IIO (1) These two reactions were studied with solid and liquid acid catalysts, and their selectivities were compared. Experimental Amberlyst 15 and Amberlite IR-120 are commercial products of Rohm and Haas. Amberlyst 15 is a macroreticular-type polystyrene sulfonic acid resin partially crosslinked with divinylbenzene. The following properties have been reported [111: surface area, 54.8 m2 g-'; porosity, 0.363 cm3 g-`. Amberlite IR-120 is a gel-type resin with negligible surface area and porosity. This type of resin needs swelling by a polar solvent in order for reactants to gain access to the interior acid sites. Nafion NR-50 was purchased from Alfa (Danvers, MA, USA). Isobutylene (99%), MHQ (99%), PHQ (97%) and TBHQ (99%) were purchased from Aldrich. Methyl N-phenyl carbamate was 239 prepared by a stoichiometric reaction between aniline and methyl chloroformate according to a known procedure [ 121. The reactions were carried out in a stirred 250 cm' borosilicate bottle (Parr). The reaction temperature was maintained by a heated silicon oil bath surrounding the reactor and measured by a mercury thermometer immersed in the reaction mixture. Hydroquinones were handled under argon atmosphere to avoid oxidation. The speed of the stirrer was chosen such that a further increase did not affect the reaction rate. After hydroquinone reactions using liquid catalysts, the products were extracted with toluene and washed 2-3 times with distilled water. The MDU product was obtained in slurry form, which was filtered and dissolved in ethyl acetate. Product recovery was easier with solid catalysts, and involved only filtration. Analysis of the products was made with a high-performance liquid chromatograph (HPLC, Waters 990). For analysis of the hydroquinones, a u,-Bondapak Cl8 column and a mobile phase of water (30-50 vol.%) in methanol containing 0.1 % triethylamine as a buffer solution were used. This condition was found to minimize oxidation of hydroquinones during analysis. For MDU, a g-Porasil column and a mobile phase of 10% ethanol in hexane were employed. The structures of the products were confirmed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and proton NMR spectroscopy. Amberlyst 15 shows much higher conversion of MHQ than Amberlite IR-120, in spite of having only one tenth the loading. On the other hand, Amberlyst 15 possesses built-in pores of 6-30 nm diameter and high surface area [ 11 ]. The activities of liquid acid catalysts follow the order of their acid strengths: trifluoromethanesulfonic acid shows the highest activity, in agreement with its superacidity [ 13 ]. The most interesting difference between solid and liquid catalysts in tbutylation of MHQ is their regioselectivity. As expected, two isomers of methyl-t-butylhydroquinones (MTBHQ) were formed: 2,5- and 2,6-MTBHQ. Solid catalysts showed much better selectivity to 2,5-MTBHQ than liquid catalysts. t-Butylation of MHQ exhibits significant solvent effects in both activity and selectivity, as shown in Table 2. For Amberlyst 15, the best results were obtained with a mixed solvent of 2-heptanone and cyclohexane. However, low-molecular-weight ketones such as acetone or methyl ethyl ketone appeared to react with hydroquinones. The byproducts from these side reactions made determining the selectivity difficult, because their HPLC peaks interfered with the peaks for 2,5-MTBHQ and 2,6-MTBHQ. When cyclohexane alone was employed, the reaction did not proceed, because the reactant MHQ was not dissolved. In the case of 70% H2S04, nonpolar solvents gave higher MHQ conversion values, yet selectivity to 2,5-MTBHQ was considerably lower than in polar solvents. Because of the poor solubility of hydroquinones in nonpolar solvents, the reaction mixture formed a slurry phase. When phenylhydroquinone (PHQ) was employed as a substrate, hydroquinone conversion values were significantly reduced, as shown in Table 3. However, selectivities to 2,5-PTBHQ were improved. Thus the difference in selectivity between liquid and solid acid catalysts was much less pronounced. Again, nonpolar cyclohexane solvent gave poor selectivity. In the case of bulkier t-butylhydroquinone as a substrate, the selectivity improved, and the difference between Amberlyst 15 and HZSOq was diminished (Table 4). Condensation of methyl N-phenyl carbamate (MPC) Condensation of MPC and formaldehyde to methylene diphenyl diurethane (MDU) was studied for various solid and liquid acid catalysts at 363 K. In all cases, 37% formalin was used as a source of HCHO. Since liquid acids were employed in great excess (60 g), they also served as solvents. Organic solvents were used for solid catalysts. Reaction products consisted of 4,4'MDU, 2,4'-MDU, trimeric urethane and the N-benzyl compound. Most noteworthy of the results summarized in Table 5 was the complete suppression of N-benzyl compound formation with solid acid catalysts; instead, their products contained more 2,4'-MDU and trimers. Sulfuric acid and Amberlyst 15 were found to be the best liquid and solid catalysts for the reaction, respectively. In the condensation of MPC with Amberlyst 15 the solvent had a considerable effect. In general, nonpolar and aprotic solvents showed good results. The reaction did not proceed at all when a polar solvent such as dimethylformamide or dimethyl sulfoxide was used. Ethyl acetate and toluene exhibited the best performance. Ethyl acetate dissolved both MPC and MDU and thus provided a homogeneous solution of products. In toluene, however, MDU was formed as a solid. In all cases, the N-benzyl compound was not formed. Discussion In the two acid-catalyzed reactions studied here, solid catalysts offer significantly better regioselectivity. This trend holds true irrespective of the reaction conditions employed, including the solvent. There are preliminary indications that this might be due to some steric effect. First, the substrates employed here were rather bulky and might be susceptible to a steric effect. Second, the observed trend in selectivity was independent of the acid strength of the catalyst. The acid strength appeared to affect only the reaction rates. Finally, the magnitude of the selectivity difference depended on the substrate with different substituents. We attempt here to rationalize the observation in terms of the known carbenium-ion chemistry of acid catalysis and the steric effect of the present reaction system. In path a, the carbenium ion attacks on of the hydroxyl groups of hydroquinone to form an ether. This ether is unstable in the presence of acid catalysts, and the t-butyl group may migrate to the vacant ortho site of the benzene ring to form a disubstituted hydroquinone. Indeed, the amount of ether detected in the early stage of the reaction was significant, and then diminished toward the end of the run. Because of the presence of the substituent R in the starting hydroquinone, attack at the neighboring hydroxyl group is sterically hindered. Thus, as observed in the present study, 2,5-disubstituted hydroquinones should be the dominant isomer in the product regardless of the catalyst system employed. Path b is a typical electrophilic aromatic substitution. Because electrophiles preferentially attack ortho and para positions of -OH, phenyl or alkyl substituents [14], and the 2,3-isomer is sterically prohibited, the 2,5- and 2,6-isomers are the expected products. From the known directing effect of substituted benzenes [14], the 2,5-isomer is more favored, owing to the substituent R (methyl, phenyl or t-butyl). With liquid catalysts, which provide free H+ or H30+, the t-butyl carbenium ion could attack hydroquinone from any direction. A salient feature of solid acids is that acid sites are fixed on the solid phase. Hence, adsorbed carbenium ion is formed, as depicted in Fig. 2. As before, the carbenium ion either forms an ether (path a) or undergoes electrophilic attack on the benzene ring (path b). Unlike with the liquid acid catalysts, however, there is much less chance that the hydroxyl group and the potential substitution site of the benzene ring located away from the resin surface are attacked by the fixed carbenium ion. Thus steric restriction of the intermediate dictates that both paths would yield predominantly 2,5-disubstituted hydroquinones. When R was changed from methyl to phenyl or t-butyl, 2,5-selectivity improved for both liquid and solid catalysts. When R was t-butyl, in particular, the diference between Amberlyst 15 and HZSOc was only marginal (Table 4). As already discussed, this may be due to the difficulty of forming an ether with a hydroxyl group next to R (path a of Fig. 1). The magnitude of this effect must follow the bulkiness of R: t-butyl > phenyl > methyl. This is exactly what was observed experimentally. In path b, selectivity between the 2,5- and the 2,6-isomer must depend on the directing effect of R to para substitution. This electronic effect is known to decrease in the order methyl > t-butyl > phenyl [ 14 ]. Hence, the observed change in regioselectivity with different R substituents indicates that path a may be a dominant reaction route in t-butylation of hydroquinones. Similar steric considerations could account for the absence of N-benzyl compound in solid-acid-catalyzed condensation of MPC to MDU. Figure 3 shows a plausible reaction mechanism, which shares a common principle with t-butylation of hydroquinones. The critical step, which decides regioselectivity, is the last one in Fig. 1: an electrophilic attack on MPC by the carbenium ion derived from condensation of HCHO and a molecule of MPC. MDU is formed by this attack on the benzene ring of MPC, while the Nbenzyl compound is formed by the attack on electron pairs of the nitrogen atom. Since the carbenium ion formed with liquid acid catalysts could move freely around the system, there exists a finite chance that the nitrogen is attacked, although the probability should be less than that for the benzene ring. It is easy to see from this structure that the probability of contact between the charged carbon atom in the carbenium ion and the nitrogen atom in MPC should be very low, owing to the steric hindrance imposed on this ion and the MPC molecule. Hence, the N-benzyl compound is not formed over solid catalysts. In summary, the two acid-catalyzed reactions studied here demonstrate that regioselectivity can be controlled by employing the solid phase in the reaction system. This controlling effect is due to steric hindrance. It is expected that this effect has been amplified in the present system, as the substrates employed are rather bulky.
